natural problem: When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$
natural solution: First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given vectors $a = [1, -1, 2]$, $b = [0, 3, 0]$ and $p$ such that $p$ is the projection of $a$ and $b$ onto some vector $v$, and that $a, b$ and $p$ are collinear, find vector $p$. The final answer is $p = [\frac{4}{7}, \frac{5}{7}, \frac{8}{7}]$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vec 3 [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vec 3 [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vec 3 [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vec 3 [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vec 3 [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vec 3 [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Let $a$ be the vector [1, -1, 2], $b$ be the vector [0, 3, 0], and $p$ be a vector such that it equals to the dot product of $a$ and $v$ divided by the dot product of $v$ and $v$, all multiplied by vector $v$. Similarly, $p$ also equals to the dot product of $b$ and $v$ divided by the dot product of $v$ and $v$, all multiplied by vector $v$. If vectors $a$, $b$, and $p$ are collinear, then find vector $p$. The final answer is the vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7].

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v = b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v = b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the vector $p$ that lies on the line connecting the vectors $a = [1, -1, 2]$ and $b = [0, 3, 0]$, such that the dot product of $p$ with any vector $v$ is equal to the weighted sum of the dot products of $a$ and $b$ with $v$, with weights given by the dot product of $v$ with itself. The final Answer is $p = [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = a *\<^sub>R (inner a v / inner v v)"
and h3 : "p = b *\<^sub>R (inner b v / inner v v)"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = a *\<^sub>R (inner a v / inner v v)"
and h3 : "p = b *\<^sub>R (inner b v / inner v v)"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given two 3D vectors $a = [1, -1, 2]$ and $b = [0, 3, 0]$, find the projection $p$ of a vector $v$ on $a$ and $b$ such that $a$, $b$, and $p$ are collinear. The final answer is $p = [\frac{4}{7}, \frac{5}{7}, \frac{8}{7}]$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. proj x v = (inner x v / (inner v v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "proj a v = p"
and h4 : "proj b v = p"
and h5 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. proj x v = (inner x v / (inner v v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "proj a v = p"
and h4 : "proj b v = p"
and h5 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given two vectors $a = [1, -1, 2]$ and $b = [0, 3, 0]$, find the vector $p$ that is the projection of both $a$ and $b$ onto a vector $v$. The projection of a vector $x$ onto $v$ is defined as $\frac{x \cdot v}{v \cdot v} * v$. If $a$, $b$, and $p$ are collinear, find the vector $p$. The final answer is $p = [\frac{4}{7}, \frac{5}{7}, \frac{8}{7}]$.

and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"

 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b v p :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given two vectors $a = [1, -1, 2]$ and $b = [0, 3, 0]$, define $p$ as the projection of $a$ and $b$ onto another vector $v$. If $a$, $b$ and $p$ are collinear, find the vector $p$. The final answer is $p = [\frac{4}{7}, \frac{5}{7}, \frac{8}{7}]$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "a \<bullet> v = b \<bullet> v"
and h3 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "a \<bullet> v = b \<bullet> v"
and h3 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given two vectors, $a = [1, -1, 2]$ and $b = [0, 3, 0]$, find a vector $p$ that is collinear with $a$ and $b$ and satisfies the dot product property $a \cdot v = b \cdot v$. The final answer is $p = [\frac{4}{7}, \frac{5}{7}, \frac{8}{7}]$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "project a v = project b v"
and h3 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "project a v = project b v"
and h3 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given vectors $a = [1, -1, 2]$ and $b = [0, 3, 0]$, find a vector $p$ that is collinear with $a$ and $b$ such that the projection of $a$ onto $v$ equals the projection of $b$ onto $v$. The final answer is $p = [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *s v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *s v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *s v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *s v"
and h4 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given vectors $a = (1, -1, 2)$ and $b = (0, 3, 0)$, and that vector $p$ is a scalar multiple of vector $v$ such that $p$ is the projection of both $a$ and $b$ onto $v$. If $a$, $b$, and $p$ are collinear, find the components of vector $p$. The final answer is $p = (4/7, 5/7, 8/7)$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
and h3 : "\<forall> v. a \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
and h4 : "\<forall> v. b \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Furthermore, the vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{p}$ are collinear.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 First, we find the line passing through $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\mathbf{p} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed);
 label("$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N); [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix},$ so
 \[\begin{pmatrix} -t + 1 \\ 4t - 1 \\ -2t + 2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(-t + 1)(-1) + (4t - 1)(4) + (-2t + 2)(-2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{3}{7}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/7 \\ 5/7 \\ 8/7 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b p v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [1, -1, 2]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 3, 0]"
and h2 : "collinear {a, b, p}"
and h3 : "\<forall> v. a \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
and h4 : "\<forall> v. b \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
shows  "p = vector [4/7, 5/7, 8/7]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given vectors $a = (1, -1, 2)$ and $b = (0, 3, 0)$, find a vector $p$ such that $p$ is collinear with $a$ and $b$ and the dot product of $p$ with any vector $v$ is the same as the dot product of $a$ and $b$ with $v$. The final answer is $p = (\frac{4}{7}, \frac{5}{7}, \frac{8}{7})$.
